Contents: Heyo thought I'd chime in here on things like Shadow, Playstation NOW and the old OnLive services; My day job is as a telecommunications network engineer in New Zealand(Help I need to escape!) we deal with alot of long distance issues as we're in the middle of nowhere. Unless someone builds some type of technology that allows data to travel faster than the speed of light there is a lot of latency hurdles for them to get over. The easiest way to fix this is deployment of multiple server farms worldwide, it's always worked great in a lab, heck I use in home streaming with steam and a laptop hooked up to my TV works great, deploying that on commercial infrastructure is a different story though. Further if I look at the connectivity rates in the US which in the majority apparently still runs on xDSL and equivalent technologies and asynchronous rates (Meaning most home connections have a lower upload than download) I don't know if we will see a workable system anytime soon, though companies like Microsoft already having server farms all over the show may be able to mitigate some of the transmission issues, newer companies are probably looking at ridiculous outlays. nan

Contents: Since Ultimate came out, many players have complained about input lag while playing online. “It's impossible to react to my opponent's attacks,” they whine. “How do I beat that guy spamming cross when my jump takes 2 seconds to register," they ask. Well, I'm here to tell you that not everyone has a problem with lag. In fact, some people adore it, pray for it, slowly caress their nether regions while thinking about it. Those people are me. I'm a dirty lagger and I'm here to tell you why lag is good. Have you ever played Smash against someone way better than you? Someone who can run circles around your character with one hand while swiping left on Tinder with the other? Someone who can eat a melting ice cream sandwich, catch all the drips with a napkin, and *still* 3-stock you? (Fuck you, Mark.) If so, lag is your new best friend. You see, lag doesn't care about fancy punish combos, short-hop-fast-fall aerials, or how quickly you can give yourself carpal tunnel syndrome by flicking a control stick back and forth. When I queue into a game running slower than a Powerpoint presentation streamed through Playstation Now, I thank our lord and savior Sakurai for the gift and crack my knuckles. Because while everyone else is preparing to play “Super Smash Bros., but slow and laggy,” I’m readying myself a completely different game. You may have heard of it; it’s called chess. I may suck at Smash, but I am a professional player of Smash chess with a rating of over 2300 Falcon kicks. I plan my moves not milliseconds, but minutes in advance. I know exactly where you are going to be long before your up-b out of shield option is a twinkle in your perfect parry’s eye. While you’re buffering your first dash grab, I’ve already planned the next 20 attacks that end with you below the stage without a sliver of hope or a second jump. Check-mate, Melee elitists. To the untrained eye, it may appear as though I stand in the center of the stage mindlessly spamming f-smashes and projectiles. However, I can assure you that the trajectory and timing of every attack has been meticulously calculated to upset your delicate ego and make you reset your game in frustration, which will only result in a 30-minute ban from online play. I am a warrior of the mind as well as a warrior of the controller. Don’t feel too bad; it’s hard to win a game you don’t even know you’re playing. See you on Big Blue. Lagger out. nan

Newegg shipped out a new one by week end that i did receive. Click to expand... Im rocking the hyper x fury s or something like that. I ordered the extra large and it is nice having a gigantic mousepad. Sounds like the shipping mistake was a one off. ====================::==================== Another major leak coming out today, and another massive rumored win for AMD: Xbox Scarlett Will Use Zen 2 and AMD Next-Gen GPU Technology; [email protected] FPS Is “On The Agenda” WCCF Tech said: According to a video report from renown Microsoft insider Brad Sams (Executive Editor of Thurrott.com), the Xbox Scarlett console, which will release in 2020, will be using Zen 2 and AMD’s next-generation GPU technology. The aim would be to have games running at 4K resolution and 60 frames per second. This would align with earlier rumors on the PlayStation 5 hardware, which pointed to an eight-core Zen CPU and a Navi-based GPU . Once again, both next-gen consoles by Sony and Microsoft could be powered by AMD technology. For the next generation, Microsoft is going to take a varied approach, releasing different types of hardware that will be able to run games through the cloud, like a cheap Xbox console that runs game via the Azure infrastructure , as well as traditional hardware. The company is going to be embracing digital distribution even further, bringing changes to the Windows Store (as promised by Phil Spencer , Executive Vice President of Gaming at Microsoft) and Xbox App and creating a unified system. Backward compatibility is also in the cards, which is not surprising considering how well it’s doing on Xbox One. All of this information has not been confirmed officially, so we have to take it with a grain of salt for the time being. If the console is indeed coming in 2020, we will finally hear more about it sometime next year, possibly at E3 2019; after all, Microsoft already announced the Xbox One X console a year and a half before it actually shipped. Click to expand... Reports are it will lean on the Cloud to gain an advantage over the PS5 which is also slated to run on AMD's Zen2 + Navi hardware : https://www.inverse.com/article/515...how-microsoft-will-use-cloud-to-beat-sony-ps5 Inverse said: Microsoft’s next Xbox console could leverage cloud technology to gain the upper hand over Sony, a report published Wednesday claims. Brad Sams, who previously reported that the upcoming “Scarlett” machine would launch in 2020, claims that the diminishing returns from more powerful hardware will push the two companies to find other ways to differentiate themselves, leading to a new tech race no longer governed by flashy specs and high resolutions. “Hardware differentiator, I think in the next gen, isn’t going to be as big of a deal as the previous gen,” Sams said, explaining how Microsoft and Sony are both likely to offer 4K resolution gaming at a smooth 60 frames per second, but consumers are unlikely to spot the difference with even higher pixel counts or framerates. This will mean offering alternative benefits, like services, price points and cloud technology. In the case of the latter, Microsoft plans to offer Netflix-like game streaming for more casual players and cloud-based processing to enhance high-end games. Microsoft announced its game streaming service in October, Project xCloud , which will leverage its 54 Azure cloud service regions to offer a variety of games without the need for downloads, running over a connection of just 10 megabits per second. The service acts as a competitor to PlayStation Now, which offers access to hundreds of PS4, PS3 and PS2 games for $19.99 per month, and xCloud is expected to start public trials in 2019. Sams previously claimed that Microsoft will offer a streaming-only “Scarlett” box for around $100, saving hundreds of dollars upfront for more casual players that are less concerned about pixel-perfect performance. Click to expand... Tweaktown said: RuthenticCookie on Reddit said that the PS5 is a beast capable of "4K/60 stable and at the same time kinda monster" and lines up with what I expect, and what I said in my report on Sony working directly with RTG engineers on the Navi GPU for the PlayStation 5. In my article, I said: "Sony needs the next-gen PS5 to truly drive 4K 60FPS if it's going to be released in 2020-2022 where 4K will be greatly established at the time. The next generation of consoles need to offer 4K 60FPS at a minimum if they want to keep up with mid-range GPUs in 2020-2027 (given that the PS5 is released in 2020, and lasts for 5-7 years)". Click to expand... If these consoles indeed drop this early, around Fall/Winter 2020, then part of me wonders if these early leaks may be misleading in representing the next generation of consoles, and if "backwards compatibility" should just be "compatibility". It's a generational overhaul, from a hardware point of view, jumping from AMD's Bobcat family (the "Jaguar" architecture) to their latest Ryzen family (Zen 2), but otherwise there doesn't look like any significant reason for these consoles to be a brand new generation rather than a [email protected] update to the current PS4/XB1 8th generation improving upon the Xbox One Elite & PS4 Pro. If the leak suggestions are correct, and this is a whole new generation of consoles, I can't wait for the same gamers who work so hard to pretend they "don't care about slight graphical improvements", like those in this recent thread , to suddenly swoon over " [email protected] BRO ", and relentlessly hype how amazing these new consoles are on those grounds to justify a purchase since at launch their game libraries will be practically nonexistent for the first year (just as they were with the PS4/XB1 all the way up to 2015). Psychology is weird like that. Gaming Hardware (& Sales) thread | Page 20

Right. It's local. When on the road around the world, accessing servers in Washington, you have an inherent very long delay just in the time it takes the signal to travel thousands of miles, let alone routing. The implication is that MS have latency down to playable across the world, despite the fact we know pings across continents can easily be 200+ ms. It's an implication that shouldn't be made, because it's borderline impossible and why these companies are trying to get servers closer to where they are needed. Contents: I don’t think I mentioned about having a cheaper store for the disc-less console as that would make no sense. I still stand by my idea though that the configurations will be as I guessed. A premium console that has the hardware onboard including a disc drive will cost he same as any new console launch. The disc less streaming console is to get those really causal players onboard for a cheaper price. They are the ones that will probably not be too fussed by millisecond delays but like the idea of having everything in the cloud. Cheaper console but perhaps more expensive over time because you can’t resell the games ====================::==================== Retro Oswald said: ↑ You don’t think they can release their XBOX Two so to speak as the true successor but also a much cheaper streaming console like Onlive did all those years ago? Click to expand... Given Onlive is no more I'm going to say no. I'd be very surprised to see a disc-less console in X2 or PS5. I just don't think a lot of the user base is after all digital. As for streaming, thats still a while off too IMO. I've not really used the PS4 PlayStation Now to try PS4 games but i'd imagine there some quality sacrifice (as well as response time) to stream that. Thats something i'm not willing to sacrifice TBH for the convenience of streaming. Contents: Neddy Seagoon posted: Out of curiosity for way down the line after I get through the Kiwami's; Is Yakuza 5 any good? It's a very different kind of game in a lot of ways and bites off a ton in terms of locations (there are five), playable characters (also five), and things you can do in the game which include things you MUST do. These extra gameplay types are neat ideas but a lot of them are insanely janky. It's a highly polarizing title because of this, depends a lot on what people will put up with. For example, there are two types of taxi missions: one where you have to get someone to their destination but have to do so with insane attention to following the rules. Stopping for pedestrians, stopping at the line for red lights, signaling for turns etc. The other is an Initial-D style balls-to-the-wall race mode. There's even a hunting mode in a remote snowy part of Hokkaido which is like Red Dead Redemption 2 light. You also go to Sapporo which is where I lived for a few years so this entry in the series is special to me as a result. There's a decently-long section in Osaka (same area as all the other games with it) where you play as Haruka, no thugs attacking you. You do, however, do Hatsune Miku-style dance-offs with people, and the storyline for her section is actually a really interesting "idol manager" game of sorts. I think a lot of people didn't like it since it was different from the bare-knuckle Yakuza fighting they were expecting, but I loved it. I think overall it has my favorite storyline since while it's all Yakuza-intertwined there's also a TON that's somewhat separate from it (e.g. the Initial-D taxi races has a whole storyline of its own, Haruka's Idol adventure, and also a disgraced baseball player and his hard-knock life story), but you definitely have to put up with a lot of roughness especially if you're used to the PS4 versions of all the games. It's the most polished of the PS3 games but that's really not saying much. If you're not sure it's on Playstation Now, too. nan

If that's the case, I'd argue that means the only food you need to eat from now on is McDonald's.. But we both know that's BS right?.. they say there are more first party studios which Phil Spencer seems to be interested in... I DREAM about a japanese studio ====================::==================== iroboto said: ↑ I’ve not commented on Sony mainly because I don’t know what they’ll do. I only know what MS is doing because it’s inline with everything else they do, subscriptions to azure, office, ML, etc. Curiously, what has Sony said? I don’t believe that Sony have the infrastructure and labour force that MS does to support such a service. I don’t think that they can effectively scale a world class streaming service to millions of users simultaneously across the world. They certainly are good at supply chain, but cloud services is not their forte. Sony isn’t an internet company, that’s not been their core strength and honestly speaking we haven’t seen them make major moves to in both careers and labour force to be able to compete with MS squarely. They don’t have the data centres and they definitely don’t have the people. Google and MS as businesses are doing their best to land as many data centres as close to people’s homes as possible to reduce latency for real time applications (self driving etc). That just happens to lend well for real time gaming too. There is a reason why Sony hasn’t been part of this particular discussion but Google has been. Anyone thinking that Sony can compete with MS in this space with equivalent margins is folly. MS’ current largest source of revenue is cloud services and they continue to invest heavily into infrastructure to support it. They’ve built the entire company around cloud and I can’t see how a company like Sony will be able to build the capital and labour force to compete properly in this space. I work for a telco, and the biggest fear right now are google, Facebook and MS barreling into the market trying to build capacity closer to the last mile to reduce latency. I’ve not heard a single word of Sony ever come up. Ever. If I do, I’ll let you know. Right now MS gaming is just piggy backing off their other services. I wouldn’t be so quick to carve it up as some brilliant strategy to win the gaming market. If this happens to be the major battleground for next gen, while Sony clearly cannot build the capability to compete, they can partner with a company that has the capability and work the market that way. Google is looking well setup to take on MS in this space. There could also be others Click to expand... MS have an important cloud service. So their infrastructure would be similar to AWS, google, and facebook. Very centralised. From interviews about the PSNow infrastructure, Sony is more like Netflix. Small rack space close to the edge. Very distributed. The theory was that datacenters are better for a cloud services because clients often need massive inter-node bandwidth and large local storage, with backup services, and be able to rent thousands of nodes in the same location. Somehow netflix has proven the gaikai method is not a bad idea at all. Microsoft Rumored to buy IO interactive | Page 3 | Beyond3D Forum
Post Title: Microsoft Rumored to buy IO interactive | Page 3 | Beyond3D Forum

After that horrific financial report, there’s just no way that GameStop can stay in business anymore. I like physical games, but I go to mom and pop stores or online if they don’t have the games I want. GameStop pricing is not that great with used games and they barely sell games anymore. Most of the stores now are taken over by toys and other stuff. People are definitely not going to GameStop to buy toys. They want games! Their used games sales have tanked dramatically this year and I hate to say it, but digital only is already here. Many people, including myself still don’t want a digital only future just yet, but look at services like Game Pass. Sony has their PSNow but they really still need to work on it and Nintendo will eventually go full on gaming Netflix like what they are doing with their older games. With game pass, you don’t really have to spend money on individual games anymore. Yes, it’s preferable to buy the game and actually own it, but you don’t really own the games you buy anymore. Every game needs a day one patch and in many cases it’s needed just to even play the games. What’s going to happen when servers shut down? The disc is more or less a license key. So, GameStop will first close down a ton of stores throughout 2019 until they have no other choice but to shutdown. To be frank, shutting down stores individually is a waste of time and money at this point for them. They should just do a full on company shut down. People don’t care enough about shopping at GameStop anymore and their time has come. The writing is on the wall and it’s sad to say, but goodbye GameStop. We all saw this coming... nan

Contents: univbee posted: It's a very different kind of game in a lot of ways and bites off a ton in terms of locations (there are five), playable characters (also five), and things you can do in the game which include things you MUST do. These extra gameplay types are neat ideas but a lot of them are insanely janky. It's a highly polarizing title because of this, depends a lot on what people will put up with. For example, there are two types of taxi missions: one where you have to get someone to their destination but have to do so with insane attention to following the rules. Stopping for pedestrians, stopping at the line for red lights, signaling for turns etc. The other is an Initial-D style balls-to-the-wall race mode. There's even a hunting mode in a remote snowy part of Hokkaido which is like Red Dead Redemption 2 light. You also go to Sapporo which is where I lived for a few years so this entry in the series is special to me as a result. There's a decently-long section in Osaka (same area as all the other games with it) where you play as Haruka, no thugs attacking you. You do, however, do Hatsune Miku-style dance-offs with people, and the storyline for her section is actually a really interesting "idol manager" game of sorts. I think a lot of people didn't like it since it was different from the bare-knuckle Yakuza fighting they were expecting, but I loved it. I think overall it has my favorite storyline since while it's all Yakuza-intertwined there's also a TON that's somewhat separate from it (e.g. the Initial-D taxi races has a whole storyline of its own, Haruka's Idol adventure, and also a disgraced baseball player and his hard-knock life story), but you definitely have to put up with a lot of roughness especially if you're used to the PS4 versions of all the games. It's the most polished of the PS3 games but that's really not saying much. If you're not sure it's on Playstation Now, too. I'm in the camp that liked 5 a lot. It's odd because the action, like the combat and mini-game variety and and the playable characters/location variety andso on makes it feel like the ultimate build up of the previous 4, but the story is so out there because of a lot of it being pretty distant from the Yakuza itself. The story's are much more personal as a result though and I liked how each person is kind of forced to live like a regular human for a little bit. It was sort of interesting because you get a lot of civilian characters who are respectable in their own way instead of just being noble victims of Yakuza machinations. Like that part in the extreme north section of Hokkaido, those folks are badass, straight up, without having to engage in the typical antics you'd get from the series' yakuza characters. But you see that sort of awakened in them as each of the playable characters enters their space, both for worse and for better. And Haruka's portion (which I loved too) really drives that home). But then the actual yakuza part of the story is as others have said pretty stupid, but I loved everything about it that wasn't directly related to that. To the point where (I know I make this post often) I think the teams' writing and the games themselves could support an entire game with no combat or high level crime lord conspiracies at all, and 5 might have been better if it went that route. Like imagine a game with Dead Souls' karaoke and each other games' best take on the various mini-games, that could be it's own weird slice of life party game thing and still be good. I love 5 just the same though. The combat is GREAT too, I think you could definitely make a case for it having the best combat on the old engines. Contents: Tkumpathenurpahl said: ↑ Streaming's come on leaps and bounds over the last few years. I don't know what PSNow's like, and xCloud is still up in the air ( ) but I can happily play Spider-Man via Remote Play, at my friend's house, which is roughly a 20 minute drive . Click to expand... Right. It's local. When on the road around the world, accessing servers in Washington, you have an inherent very long delay just in the time it takes the signal to travel thousands of miles, let alone routing. The implication is that MS have latency down to playable across the world, despite the fact we know pings across continents can easily be 200+ ms. It's an implication that shouldn't be made, because it's borderline impossible and why these companies are trying to get servers closer to where they are needed. You can just build one epic installation in some cheap country and serve the whole world from there. ====================::==================== iroboto said: ↑ Yea passive cooling ? Did I use that term incorrectly? It doesn't have it's own cooler and relies on the rack Click to expand... I think once you are required to move a fluid (air or liquid) to promote cooling during normal operation you are no longer passively cooled, but I'm not certain of the textbook definition. Contents: Just to clarify, are you asking if PlayStation Now (the streaming service) is worth it or if the PlayStation console itself is worth buying now? In terms of PlayStation Now, I tried it for three months and I enjoyed it. I got to play the Infamous games (which I love), the Ratchet and Clank games and some Arkham games as well. I don’t play often though and I think buying a year subscription would be a waste of money for me. If you only see a few games you are interested in playing, try the trial or purchase a month and see how it works for you. As for the PlayStation itself, I love it. Again, I’m not a massive gamer but I’ve liked this console more than my PS3 or Xbox consoles. I just recently got into VR and besides for the move controllers, it’s pretty awesome. I even bought a brand new PC that can handle almost anything recently and still find I’m going back to the PS4 more times than not. My suggestion is if you aren’t sold on it, don’t go for it. If you are sold on it but times are tight in terms of money, wait til you can afford it. I promise, you aren’t missing out on something that won’t be around in the future so there’s no rush. If you’ve got nothing to lose, give it a go... nan

You're renting the games to stream, just like Netflix is a renting service, once you stop paying you lose access to the games, the same with Gamepass. You trying to play semantics won't change that fact. And Sony did it first with PSNow. Saying that Sony would be still using memory cards if it weren't for MS is like saying the Xbox would still be using cartridges if it wasn't for the PS1 which introduced CD. It's stupid nonsense, the fact is that the industry was already starting to move forward away from memory cards due to games becoming more demanding. The PS2 introduced official support for external hdd before the Xbox even released BTW. Sony had crossplay with PC in games like FFXIV (which MS still doesn't allow), Portal 2, Dust 514, Eve Online and many more with Vita. They even had crossplay on PS2 games with PC way before MS had any. You didn't easily discredited anything. You damage controlled them out of pure ignorance real or pretended. nan

Contents: RDR2 is likely to come to PC next year. GTA V had a late release for PC and has proved to make quite a bit of money for them. In addition to monetary boost, another key aspect is that due to many factors, the PC gaming scene has seen a huge resurgence the past few years. RDR1 probably isn't worth the effort to port to PC but can be played on PC via PSNow subscription. That said, it's quite obvious due to the hardware requirements and sheet size of the game why it's not coming to switch. Would it be great if they did? Sure. But at some point you have to ask yourself if it's really worthwhile for both the consumer and producer to undertake this large task and in the end, it seems it didn't add up which is fine. 2019 seems like a big year for switch. I'm a future switch owner (Christmas!) And mainly PC gamer nan

Contents:
New Post has been published on https://www.articletec.com/project-stream-everything-we-know-about-googles-game-streaming-service-2/

Project Stream: Everything we know about Google’s game streaming service






Imagine your friend invests in a new GPU to upgrade their already expensive gaming PC so they can play the latest blockbuster video game. Now imagine you open the Chrome browser, and then open a new tab to play the very same video game. While your friends computer kicks into high gear, fans blistering, your computer (perhaps even a Chromebook) stays cool and quiet, because all you’re doing is streaming. 

That’s the idea of Google’s Project Stream cloud gaming service.

Rather than needing high-end hardware, Project Stream allows you to use whatever computer you have around to play video games. Google handles all the heavy lifting on its own servers, which can process the game at high resolutions and frame rates, encode it into a stream, and deliver the stream to you over the internet.

It may sound almost too good to be true, and only time will tell if it is. Right now, the Project Stream service is in Beta. And, while it’s not perfect, it gets the job done, and serves as an impressive showcase of what the future of cloud gaming could look like.

How Project Stream works

It’s not clear how the final product will work, whether Google will maintain the Project Stream name, or even whether Google will continue the project after this beta. But, for the moment, as long as you’re connected to the internet with a fast and stable connection and you’re using a recent desktop version of the Chrome browser, you’ve got the setup needed to use Project Stream. 

Playing a video game on Project Stream is as simple as opening a new tab in Chrome and going to the Projectstream.google.com page.  

Google will prompt you to run a connection test that checks your internet bandwidth, the latency between your computer and the servers, and any data loss. Google requires a streaming rate of 15Mbps, latency below 40ms, and data loss below 5%. With these requirements met, you’ll be ready to dive into a game.

The beta of Project Stream is offering Assassin’s Creed Odyssey, which is nothing short of a demanding title. When you launch the game in your Chrome tab, it will go fullscreen, and run exactly as if it has been launched on a proper gaming computer (except without a deep graphics settings menu). You can play with a keyboard and mouse or connect a game controller and play that way.



All of your inputs on the computer get sent over to Google’s servers, processed in the game, and everything happening gets streamed right back to you. This is why that latency is so important, because you can’t have a good game experience if everything you do in the game shows up a second later.

The limits of Project Stream haven’t been detailed, but Google has shown off the service running at 1080p and 60fps, pretty much the bar for quality PC gaming. 

All of your inputs on the computer get sent over to Google’s servers, processed in the game, and everything happening gets streamed right back to you.

So, in effect, you’re opening a new tab that pipes all your inputs to a high-end gaming PC that streams back the visuals and audio to your computer screen. This system is simpler than some others, which set you up with a virtual desktop that then remotely runs Steam, Origin, Battle.net, or what have you.

In the case of Assassin’s Creed Odyssey on Project Stream, you are still required to log into a Ubisoft account to play, but beta testers aren’t required to own the game.

It’s unclear at this point whether Google will require players to buy games and pay for the streaming service in separate transactions, or whether access to select games will be bundled into the service.

What games will be available on Project Stream?

Through the Project Stream beta, the only available game is Assassin’s Creed Odyssey. While this doesn’t give us much idea of what games Google will offer in the future, it does give us a good idea of what games Google could be capable of offering. 

For a 1080p 30fps game experience at High settings in Assassin’s Creed Odyssey, Ubisoft recommends a system with the following specs:

 * OS: Windows 7 SP1, Windows 8.1, Windows 10 (64-bit versions only) 
 * Processor: AMD FX-8350 @ 4.0 GHz, Ryzen 5 – 1400, Intel Core i7-3770 @ 3.5 GHz 
 * Video: AMD Radeon R9 290 or NVIDIA GeForce GTX 970 (4GB VRAM or more with Shader Model 5.0) or better 
 * Memory: 8GB RAM 
 * Video Preset: High 
 * Storage: 46GB available hard drive space 
 * DirectX: DirectX June 2010 Redistributable 
 * Sound: DirectX 9.0c compatible sound card with latest drivers 
For 4K at 30fps and high settings, the recommended specs bump up to include 16GB of RAM, a more powerful AMD Ryzen 1700X or Intel Core i7 7700 processor, and a beefier AMD Vega 64 or Nvidia GeForce GTX 1080 graphics card. With Project Stream shooting for 1080p at 60fps, the type of system it’s offering would fall somewhere between Ubisoft’s recommended specs.

The truth is a computer that can handle Assassin’s Creed Odyssey at 1080p 60fps is going to be capable of playing a whole lot of games at these settings. Other major titles could easily see support on the service.

Games with a major online focus may have dicier prospects on Project Stream. Since competitive online games are often fast-paced and require split-second reaction times, the extra latency introduced by streaming will likely be an issue for serious competitors. That said, we don’t see these games being unplayable on the service.



What’s Project Stream like to use?

At its best, Project Stream is good. At its worst, well, Google won’t let you play below a certain threshold of quality, and you wouldn’t want to anyway.

We tested Project Stream on varying setups. We played on an unstable 2.4GHz Wi-Fi connection, a fast and nearby 5GHz Wi-Fi connection, and on an ethernet connection held steady and offered high bandwidth. 

The highly dated Chromebook hardware didn’t hold it back from playing.

We also played on a 5-year-old Chromebook, a 2-year-old Razer Blade, and a modern desktop gaming rig that would be happy to run Assassin’s Creed Odyssey at 1080p/60FPS on its own hardware. We even started one computer up while another was running the stream, and Google simply transferred control over to the second computer, with no stop in the stream.

Across the board, we’d describe the experience as at least playable. The highly dated Chromebook hardware didn’t hold it back from playing. The biggest issues come from a bad connection: if the connection speed drops, so does the game quality, with lower resolutions, latency, and far more noticeable compression. 

That said, in our experience, the visual degradation came before the latency, so we were able to continue battling enemies smoothly even if they started to look like ghostly swarms of pixels.

Overall, the graphics are fairly good throughout, especially when playing on a high-bandwidth connection using ethernet cables. Colors, shadows, and anti-aliasing look fine, and the frame-rate seems to vary between 30 and 60fps.



The low frame-rate was one of the two issues we noticed. The other was compression. Most of the time, it’s not super jarring, but when there’s a lot of detail in a scene and a lot of movement, the compression turns it all into a bit of slop. Character faces become a blur and hard edges (noticeably the character’s hair) go soft. 

It would seem to be a sign of the lower bitrate enabling this type of streaming, but the truth is that most of the time it’s unnoticeable, and would be even harder to spot if you weren’t looking for it (we were looking for it). Panning the camera and running through dense wooded areas in the game (and combining the two) were the only times we were turned off by the dips in visual quality.

The experience isn’t mind-blowing, at least until you remember that it’s using so little of your computers processing power that you’ve literally got a full-system virus scan going in the background and nothing changed. The visuals are comparable to what you’d get on a console, except with compression artifacts here and there. And, with a stable connection, it compares rather favorably to in-home streaming on a Steam Link.

While the price and service model Google adopts will go a long way in determining whether Project Stream is worthwhile, we can say right now that it works, and it looks good doing it. But, will Microsoft’s xCloud do it better?

 * Looking for a fully baked game streaming service? PlayStation Now is available now 


Source link Project Stream: Everything we know about Google's game streaming service

I agree with you, but to say Sony is leaps and bounds behind is just play fan-boyism. Sony has an analogous service to Gamepass with hundreds of more games to choose from, albeit streamed to your console. I do prefer Gamepass and subscribe to it and not PSnow. But they boast very different benefits: Gamepass boasts game accessibility; while PSnow boasts a giant library to choose from. Also, Sony does support cross-platform with PC for some titles, and was a big proponent of cross-play in the past, only to be snubbed by Microsoft. That being said, to truly be cross-platform, Microsoft needs Sony buy-in and vice-versa, so the day we do see true cross-platform support it will be ubiquitous across platforms by definition. As for mods, I played Fallout 4 with mods on my PS4, so again, just in my own experience, "leaps and bounds" is categorically incorrect. I do know that Microsoft is more lenient about what mod content is allowed, so maybe I'd call it "skips and hops" above PS4 mod support. I can wholeheartedly agree that the adaptive controller does put Microsoft uniquely leaps and bounds above Sony when it comes to disabled players, albeit for a niche group of gamers. Overall, I'd agree with you that Microsoft services, but you pretty much define my issue with the Xbox this generation: >So far, it looks like they've been focusing on is improving on what it means to be a console It seems Microsoft got to caught up in improving what it means to be a console and forgot the ultimate service a console provides: playing games, and Sony was leaps and bounds above Microsoft when it came to providing that service by providing the best games of the generation on the ps4. I'm surprised you brought up a lot of moot points and forgot backwards compatibility which is probably one of the singular ways Microsoft is in fact leaps and bounds above Sony... nan

Contents: Damn, when I was smaller, I played LEGO starwars and LEGO starwars the original trilogy with my brother, I recently got LEGO starwars 3 the clone wars on psnow, and it was honestly really good. I think I’ve enjoyed it more then more recent starwars games (battlefront 2 EA) because they’re more to do, they have mini games, they have more story content, I actually care about the storyline, as I watched the original clone wars series. Battlefront 2 EA is too simple? I guess I could say that. Pick up a blaster, aim and click. It plays like a call of duty game with more health and in space. The LEGO games are made to be simple but they’re not boring. They have puzzles, and so much content. So many characters to choose from. I don’t really care if battlefront 2 is the best looking game out, it is honestly really bare bones and devoid of content. I think there are only like 10 maps or something, and 10 or so heroes on each side. I think there are 52 LEGO starwars 3 missions (I’m probably wrong) and I know there are a shitload of characters. I’m not sure if there was dlc or not, but it feels like a complete game. Battlefront 2, where is mace windu? Where is Jango fett? Ashoka tano, Aayla secura, luminara, asajj ventress, commando droids, captain rex and captain Cody? Where are the Jedi starfighters? Why are there so few maps? Christophsis? Utapau? Dantooine? Battlefront 2 feels devoid of content, and I would rather have more content then the best looking game. I would rather pay for DLC that’s completely full of content, like take up my whole console space, then get 2 heroes and a map for free in a year. I’m glad I didn’t pay the $60 asking price for battlefront 2, but if my ps3 had worked, I would have probably more then gladly paid the asking price for LEGO starwars 3. nan

Contents: Little is known about the next generation of gaming consoles at this point, with Sony and Microsoft notorious for keeping their cards close to their chests. ​ Both the Xbox and PlayStation are due upgrades, however, and the technology giants could be looking to release new models as soon as 2019. One of the most exciting pieces of news is the fact that Microsoft may be working on a disc-less console, which could bring about major changes in the gaming market. ​ Recent reports from Thurrott suggest that Microsoft is planning to move away from discs for its consoles to lower the price point of the hardware and make it more affordable. Players who have a large collection of discs will be able to exchange them for the digital download version of the game and play them on the new console. This represents a massive step forward in the evolution of gaming, and discs could become outdated in the next few years. According to Statista , digital sales overtook physical all the way back in 2013. And last year, a whopping 79 percent of video game sales in the US were downloads. Some sectors of the entertainment industry have already moved towards fully integrated online platforms that don’t require software. In the iGaming sector, sites have become hubs for countless games that players can access instantly without having to download. At Sloty.com , for instance, there are hundreds of popular slot games such as Starburst and Game of Thrones, which can be accessed in a matter of seconds. However, with graphically complex and resource-intensive console offerings, it may not be possible to have instant play options like this. There are some services like PlayStation Now and Xbox Game Pass that allow users to stream games through the cloud, but actually doing this through the user's console would be a leap forward. The introduction of 5G internet will speed everything up, and could make previously inconceivable things a reality. The idea behind a move towards disc-less entertainment has been made possible by Netflix, which has changed the game and made physical discs almost superfluous. The streaming service has reduced the number of people buying movies and box sets, and instead allowed them to have access to a whole library of series and films within the Netflix application. In ten years, the company founded by Reed Hastings and Marc Randolph in 1997 has gone from having seven million subscribers in the US, to 90 million people worldwide. It has led to other competing services including Amazon Prime and HBO NOW, and a lot of filmmakers are now gearing their content towards these platforms. Many people are now wondering whether the console industry will go in the same direction as services like Netflix. It isn’t out of the question to think that physical discs could be obsolete in the near future, with downloads being the only source of obtaining new games. This could increase sales, as there would be less sharing of games between friends. Are We Heading Towards an Entirely Digital Gaming Market?
Post Title: Are We Heading Towards an Entirely Digital Gaming Market?

Contents: Over the past couple of years, 2K has become a game made for "gamers" as opposed to "basketball fans", with massive mainstream success with the Fortnite crowd who have no idea about basketball other than Steph Curry highlights they see on YouTube. This is the major reason for people you play with randomly having zero basketball IQ. The other night we were in a squad trying to play zone defense, and 2 of the guys on our team didn't even know what the "baseline" was... it's emblematic of the community as a whole. The neighbourhood is basically PlayStation Now crossed with the Sims with a bit of basketball thrown in. Plus "gamers" have been conditioned only to care about getting the "high score" or "highlight play", and many of them are socially awkward in general. The amount of idiots in Rec Centre who get on the mic and shout "PASSS I'M OOOOPPPEENNNN" (typically with a high pitch voice as their balls have not yet dropped) every. single. time. down the court is ridiculous as well. 2K = McDonald's or Wal-Mart, and now attracts the same scum those places do. nan

I've been subscribed to the Playstation Now service and it is really a great way to collect games and such and with the download features, this makes it even better. They offered Mafia III last month and decided to give it a shot. I'm loving it and still playing it because I still haven't beaten it. I found the game pretty solid with such a well-done storytelling and engrossing world. Before I started it, many sites gave it average to below average ratings which made me reluctant but went on it, anyway. Like I said, I love it and the storytelling is so damn unique for an open-world GTA type game. So, what am I missing? I'm now deep in the game and still can't find it as a bad game. There were some frustration things here and there but what game doesn't have that. I played and finished Spiderman (except the last DLC) and that frustrated me more than Mafia III. And I simply explained why - there are many PS4 exclusives that you can't play on a HTPC and so you may want a PS4. Not sure why you think I'm the one that's "triggered" when you told me to fuck off for answering your question. So if you want a watercooled system but you want to play PS4 exclusives then you want a watercooled PS4, plus you get the same benefits watercooling a PS4 as watercooling anything, the system runs quieter and cooler. PS4 fans being loud when they spin up to high RPMs is a pretty common complaint, and a cooler system is a longer lasting system. Also, I would beg to differ on the gains, I would be surprised if a system that stays cooler isn't less likely to drop frames or stutter when things get intense on screen. The reason I said you're taking nonsense is your comments about "using an htpc to use the console's online services" and "being able to stream almost the entire library of either console" are quite obviously false, all you can access is Playstation Now, which lets you stream select PS4 games, about 200 of the close to 2 thousand games that PS4 owners have access to. Even from my list above only Driveclub, Bloodborne, Until Dawn and The Last of Us (PS3 only) are on there, and it's nothing like actually playing on a PS4 anyway as streaming introduces latency that playing directly doesn't. If you just like to watercool stuff but already have a watercooled gaming PC like OP does then buying and watercooling a PS4 over building a watercooled HTPC makes a lot of sense. It might be more of a challenge but it gets you access to games that a second PC does not. nan

Says who regarding the ''metric changing"? PSNow has more subscriptions and have doubled Xbox console sales. I'm pretty sure MS cares that they were beaten nearly 2-1 in hardware sales this gen. Again, they wouldn't be doing what they are doing if they didn't. nan

Contents: The_Mike said: Don’t get me wrong. Of course they worked on it. But you can’t deny they got a lot of help by Microsoft being busy demolishing themselves during the beginning of this gen. But after they’ve won the race by a large margin, they haven’t really done anything, while Microsoft (and even Nintendo ) has progressed to win over players while Sony rose the wave that was based on luck, skill and their competitors fucking up. For sure they benefited from MS forking up, but it takes skill, preparation, and ability to execute to take advantage of opportunities like this. To paraphrase a well liked Raymond E. Feist character “luck is preparation + opportunity”. Honestly, it feels like the narrative sometimes becomes “Sony has dominated for most of the past 25 years basing mostly on luck and competitors fucking up while whenever their competitors managed to score wins it was based only on their efforts and skills and not on luck and their competitors fucking up”. IMHO, Sony kept doing well while MS played catchup and this worked harder than Sony in relative terms and much harder than they did launching the machine launching two revisions where they improved performance and features in each (Xbox One S has slightly higher clocks than Xbox One too). I do not think Sony has been resting on their laurels: they kept going according to plan (PS4 is not short of amazing first and third party software, they did concede on crossplay, they kept improving PSNow, and they finally moved to fix their massive long database issue that did not allow for PSN User ID changes as embarrassing of a legacy as it was..., and prepped and launched a cost effective strong machine like PS4 Pro and tons of exclusives) and are working on PS5 too. EAims posted... I feel like every year there are several topics dedicated to "the end is near for gamestop". Because the end is near for GameStop. 1) GameStop's business model, while currently successful, is exploitative of consumers, and has thus earned the company a great deal of ill will among its customer base. People only shop with GameStop because of the diversity of titles they stock compared to competing retailers such as Best Buy and Walmart. Once digital distribution becomes the standard for consoles as it is with PC, people won't care about GameStop because they'll be able to find the same games for the same price, or cheaper, through the PlayStation Store. 2) GameStop's business model has not effectively evolved with the times. GameStop realized a decade ago that digital distribution was going to be the future, and rightfully bought Impulse from Stardock. However, how well has GameStop marketed that service? How aggressive have they been in making Impulse (Now called the GameStop App) competitive with Steam, GOG, Origin, and UPlay? GameStop allowed Impulse to languish, and instead invested in side businesses that won't make the kind of margins that GameStop makes from used games. Said investments include a mobile carrier business (which GameStop recently sold for a large influx of cash), and selling toys, t-shirts and collectibles, but the latter has not proven to be a viable alternative revenue stream. 3) Sony and Microsoft have gone from offering digital distribution services such as Xbox Live Arcade and the PlayStation Store as supplemental services to reach an untapped market, to aggressively pushing digital platforms such as Xbox Game Pass and PlayStation Now. Microsoft was prepared to make the Xbox One a primarily digital platform, but their botched unveiling stalled that effort. However, with the current rumor that Microsoft's Next Box will come in a SKU that only streams games, and a SKU with no disc drive, it is clear that digital distribution on consoles will inevitably become the new standard, at which point GameStop will no longer have physical media to sell. The fact of the matter is that when a particular business fails, it is rarely immediate, or unexpected. It often takes years of missteps, missed opportunities, and inevitable obsolescence, but it happens. People still buy DVDs and Blu Ray discs, but Blockbuster and Hollywood Video no longer exist, as they were made irrelevant thanks to Netflix. Just like Blockbuster, so too will GameStop vanish, having failed to adapt to changes in consumer behavior. We are witnessing the decline of a giant, so enjoy the show. It won't be long before GameStop becomes the subject of a Company Man video on YouTube. https://youtu.be/5sMXR7rK40U nan

ultragpu said: ↑ So this guy claims to have insider knowledge about MS's strategy. Basically a discless streaming box and a traditional physical box, both using Zen 2 and AMD's next gen "upcoming gen" gpu and releasing at the same time as Sony at 2020. Click to expand... The discless box is a Thurrott rumor and the other stuff is a rehash of digital foundry and AdoredTV rumor/speculation. Edit: didn’t realize this was Brad Sams. Makes sense they’d repeat their own rumor ====================::==================== Shifty Geezer said: ↑ That's not a good answer. It's open to the imagination, with people thinking he's playing action games seamlessly. What games is he playing, and what's the latency like? We know there are physical limits regards transfer times, and we know that part of the way to reduce latency is to move servers nearer users rather than route across thousands of miles. We know streaming games works because others have already been doing it for years, and we know it's not ideal but an okay experience, particularly for some genres. Spencer's comment doesn't build on that any - are they lower latency? Or is the experience similarly a compromise? Click to expand... Streaming's come on leaps and bounds over the last few years. I don't know what PSNow's like, and xCloud is still up in the air ( ) but I can happily play Spider-Man via Remote Play, at my friend's house, which is roughly a 20 minute drive. This, on my smartphone, from my WiFi connected PS4Pro. Having the consoles located in server farms will be a further improvement. If they can beef up the server hardware to render at 60 or 120 fps, so dropped frames matter less, that'll further improve it. If the local streaming consoles are capable of frame interpolation and upscaling, that'll further improve it too. I used to be pretty skeptical about game streaming, and I'll always want to play the likes of Spider-Man on local hardware, but the tech's already there to make my sub-optimal situation viable in the suburbs of a fairly minor British city. Little boxes with a mostly stable, barely laggy 30fps will be good enough for most people. Xbat said: ↑ Well looking at those Navi performance rumours it looks like 1080ti performance will be the upper limit for next gen? Click to expand... Does it necessarily? Even if those rumours are true, we only really have confirmation about cards which seem designed to appeal to a broad range of the market, whilst conceding they have nothing to go toe to toe with the RTX2080 in 2019. PlayStation Network services are currently offline, which means online gaming, shopping, and communication is currently unavailable on the PS4. The PlayStation Network service status page states account management, gaming and social, PlayStation Now; Vue; Video; Store; and Music are all inaccessible. 

“You may have some difficulty launching games, applications, or online features,” a message on the site reads. “Our engineers are working to resolve the issue as soon as possible, and we thank you for your patience.”

Based on messages directed at the various PlayStation support accounts on Twitter, it looks like the outage is widespread, with users both in the US and Europe reporting issues with connectivity. Sony has not provided a timeframe for when it expects services to be up and running again. The actual cause of the issue has also not been detailed.

With any luck, the problems won’t be severe and the service should be up and running again soon. Of course, outage at this time of the year immediately sparks memories of 2011, when PlayStation Network was severely compromised by hackers. In that situation, services were not restored for a significant length of time.

Contents: Tkumpathenurpahl said: ↑ Streaming's come on leaps and bounds over the last few years. I don't know what PSNow's like, and xCloud is still up in the air ( ) but I can happily play Spider-Man via Remote Play, at my friend's house, which is roughly a 20 minute drive . Click to expand... Right. It's local. When on the road around the world, accessing servers in Washington, you have an inherent very long delay just in the time it takes the signal to travel thousands of miles, let alone routing. The implication is that MS have latency down to playable across the world, despite the fact we know pings across continents can easily be 200+ ms. It's an implication that shouldn't be made, because it's borderline impossible and why these companies are trying to get servers closer to where they are needed. You can just build one epic installation in some cheap country and serve the whole world from there. ====================::==================== True, locality does matter. I think it's worth reading that part of the Quote: again. Phil Spencer said: Spencer concluded by talking about the issue of latency while streaming games. He mentioned that he’s already streaming games while he’s on the road around the world, and the test servers for Project xCloud are still in Washington, but Azure has a global scale. Click to expand... The last sentence just merges together a couple of details that deserve more time: - "already streaming games while he’s on the road around the world, and the test servers for Project xCloud are still in Washington" says virtually nothing, because we've no idea what the quality's like and, as you said, no idea the kinds of games he's playing or the limitations of the tech. - "but Azure has a global scale" is the bit I'm focusing on. Anywhere that has Azure servers will get some quantity of xCloud servers and my understanding is that Azure's quite widespread. So, I think it's poor reporting, not a poor response. All of this game streaming malarkey makes me curious if the pyramids are actually for streaming Assassins Creed Origins across every corner of the universe, but the Sphinx is missing her aerial. I'm going to go there with my Vita and a wire coat hanger. Next Generation Hardware Speculation with a Technical Spin [2018] | Page 198

Contents: Hello Reddit! I enjoy building my own PC, however, I am learning web development and I find the need for portability (it is easier for me to focus in places Starbuck/Barnes and Noble where I don't have distractions). I've done one of those coding boot-camps and used a surface book and when doing larger files the surface book started having difficulty keeping up. Because of this I have been looking more and more at gaming laptops because of their performance and foregoing a custom PC build. I would honestly still prefer a custom build and using a cheap laptop or Chromebook. My question is this; is it possible for me to build a PC and buy a cheap laptop that can access my PC's performance remotely? I know cloud computing (such as PlayStation Now and Liquid Sky) lets you play games on a remote server similar to Netflix. Also, Microsoft has a built in remote desktop feature in Windows but I don't know how the performance is (I am trying to avoid a lag). Is what I want to do possible? nan

Contents: "So we built Xbox Game Pass -- it started on console, it will come to PC, and eventually it will come to every device -- we use the flywheel that we have with customers on an Xbox to start the growth in Xbox Game Pass. But as somebody sitting back and taking a longer-term view of where our business is going, you should look at that as a business model that we think scales to billions of people not hundreds of millions of people like retail does." ... However, the most interesting implication is that Microsoft might seek to bring its Game Pass service to PlayStation and Nintendo devices. Spencer's comments weren't limited to "console, then PC, then mobile" -- he instead said "every device". https://www.gamesindustry.biz/artic...ncer-xbox-game-pass-will-come-to-every-device Personally, I didn't need an Xbox at all this generation because almost all of its big games released on PC (cross-play). This would essentially seal the deal for me to never buy one again. All 3 console makers will have to adapt to service-based gaming. It will be up to them to keep their hardware relevant in the age of subscription and streaming (if it really catches on). ====================::==================== the_wire30 said: ↑ I don't see Nintendo and Sony making their recent games available outside of their exclusive ecosystem though, at least not anytime soon (next 5 years) Click to expand... Not sure why you don’t think Sony would do it when they were the “first” to do it in 2014 lol (They allowed you to access PlayStation games outside of ps4...TVs and handhelds and blu ray players and media players) Sony was the first to allow legacy Sony games accessible on the pc in 2016 (Microsoft was already planning it and did so later in 2016) Now Xbox is allowing Gamepass access on Pc (with xboxone games included)...why wouldn’t Sony be planning something similar? Once Gamepass became a thing, Sony moved to allow their PsNow games to start being downloadable (rather than just streamed)...no doubt to give a better gaming experience for PsNow Oddly enough, once Microsoft announced their big plans for streaming and Gamepass access across multiple devices, Sony pulled PsNow support from ps3/vita/roku/playstation tv/blue ray players and all TVs except Bravia last year. The reason given was that they wanted to focus on windows PC...so they could “develop and improve” their PsNow service. They are absolutely re working and planning on expanding their gaming service outside of PlayStations to compete/coincide with Microsoft services on other devices. They would be foolish not to untie their service from PlayStation hardware going forward. ...and beyond that who knows what will happen. We might all be playing a Google console in 10 years lol. Click to expand... lol, the driving force for dedicated gaming hardware is still casuals right now. Don’t put too much stock in mass market dedicated consoles...even if it’s google If people in 10 years can get access to AAA multiplats on any of the devices they own, they aren’t going to pay $200-$500 for a console anymore. Only core/hardcore gamers will, so you are looking at Gamcube/n64 type sales for high end, 3rd party gaming home consoles in the future . Xbox Game Pass “will come to every device”

Contents: Looks like anyone living in Chicago will start paying 9% more for Plus and Now thanks to their brilliant "Cloud Tax". Quote: : Sony issued a warning to users in Chicago (thanks, USGamer), signalling Chicago's Amusement Tax begins on 14th November, and so will collect nine per cent more from PlayStation Plus and PlayStation Now, among other PlayStation subscription services. The Amusement Tax does not apply to sales of video games. So, if you're in Chicago and buy a game from the PlayStation Store, you don't have to pay extra. Rather, it applies only to rentals (considered streaming or temporary downloads), where the charges are subscription fees, per-event fees or otherwise, which is why Plus and Now are affected. "The charges paid for such rentals may be subscription fees, per-event fees or otherwise," the law stipulates. Chicago's Amusement Tax, which was designed to apply to live events but has been successfully extended to online services, is the first of its kind in America. Sony has joined companies such as Netflix and Spotify in collecting the tax, but a number of businesses are challenging it on a legal basis. Apple, for example, has lodged a complaint against the city of Chicago over it. It's expected PC, Xbox and Nintendo customers will be similarly affected, pending any legal challenge. https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2...Js-wavpRQm80Vc ====================::==================== Why wouldn't they be? Sales tax is a state law. Digital products have been taxable in other states for a while. Best complain to your local legislators. Good luck Chicago introduces 9% "Cloud Tax" for PlayStation Plus/Now Users
Post Title: Chicago introduces 9% "Cloud Tax" for PlayStation Plus/Now Users

Contents: Yeah, you know, when I think about who I see as our long-term competitors over the next decade in this gaming category, I think you're going to see the big tech companies that Microsoft competes with in many different areas entering. And you see it. Amazon has Amazon Game Studios. They have for a while. AWS has a very large workload in the gaming space. Google has just started working on Project Stream. And they are -- you can see the work that they're starting to do to enter this category. Tencent is a huge gaming company. https://view.officeapps.live.com/op...?version=65af4809-9575-21b7-784d-aaf4da3823c6 There should be no surprise of this, both companies have the Cloud infrastructure to scale globally, both have the money and platforms to allow Cloud gaming to happen. Sony has none of this other than PS4. The fundamental fact is, you need data centers in physical locations in other to reduce latency. Microsoft, Google and Amazon are investing aggressively in this field and Sony hasn't anything. If you want to know why PSNow has a very small availability, lack of global data centers is why. @devnull520 I won't argue the merits of PC ports and the problems with a statement like "oh it is on PC also so who cares", however: Myself being a playstation MVP and being bent against PSNow from the beginning, there are way too many factors that benefit an embedded gaming machine over any sort of streaming service. First of all streaming has lag and collisions, the technology isn't coming to fix this to a level where the embedded device will become "useless". Secondly the platform itself is standardized and in a controlled environment. This is the primary benefit of an embedded system along with proprietary technologies shared by first party developers. This is why the PC gaming platform just doesn't quite measure up even though the hardware is leaps and bounds ahead. The "streaming PC" is a not a fix here either because no matter how much control the service provider wants, the streaming client is still at the mercy of the platform it is running on. Finally (but there is much more in the weeds), the customer isn't going to want the streaming service. A pay to play service coupled with a subpar experience will never replace an embedded device for a purpose that stands alone without requiring a fee. Trust me, I have written 3 different letters to Sony about PSNow after several alpha rollouts I participated in. It is a poor technology choice and the first company to push for it by itself instead of an embedded device is going to go bankrupt. nan

Contents: You really think you can play a 60 GB game in the cloud? Expect to have 30 minute load times per level if you did that. They already do something similar to that: Playstation Now, which has the game running "in the cloud" and you just are the controller and display. ====================::==================== They do have something like that. However, it is only used for saving game progress, not the actual game. Xbox One and PS4 games are very large, usually 50+ gigabytes in size. Unless you have a very, very fast Internet connection, it would be very difficult to stream a game over the Internet without loosing any quality and maintaining good FPS and not have the game unresponsive. My thought is that it wouldn't work very well for most people. What are people who have very slow internet supposed to do? Why do gaming systems (ps4/xbox/switch) not have cloud storage for all the games?

Contents: Tkumpathenurpahl said: ↑ Streaming's come on leaps and bounds over the last few years. I don't know what PSNow's like, and xCloud is still up in the air ( ) but I can happily play Spider-Man via Remote Play, at my friend's house, which is roughly a 20 minute drive . Click to expand... Right. It's local. When on the road around the world, accessing servers in Washington, you have an inherent very long delay just in the time it takes the signal to travel thousands of miles, let alone routing. The implication is that MS have latency down to playable across the world, despite the fact we know pings across continents can easily be 200+ ms. It's an implication that shouldn't be made, because it's borderline impossible and why these companies are trying to get servers closer to where they are needed. You can just build one epic installation in some cheap country and serve the whole world from there. ====================::==================== Tkumpathenurpahl said: ↑ I wonder how similar the server hardware will be to the home console hardware. And if they're similar, I wonder if Microsoft will be cheeky and utilise idle consoles for its own purposes? Running some ML algorithm, for example. Click to expand... EU power regulations say no. The home user could opt-in FaH-style, but that removes the cheekiness,no? Besides, there's no need for hardware parity to make this work. Any connected console with compute resources could be used this way with the proper software running. Next Generation Hardware Speculation with a Technical Spin [2018] | Page 198

Contents: Tkumpathenurpahl said: ↑ Streaming's come on leaps and bounds over the last few years. I don't know what PSNow's like, and xCloud is still up in the air ( ) but I can happily play Spider-Man via Remote Play, at my friend's house, which is roughly a 20 minute drive . Click to expand... Right. It's local. When on the road around the world, accessing servers in Washington, you have an inherent very long delay just in the time it takes the signal to travel thousands of miles, let alone routing. The implication is that MS have latency down to playable across the world, despite the fact we know pings across continents can easily be 200+ ms. It's an implication that shouldn't be made, because it's borderline impossible and why these companies are trying to get servers closer to where they are needed. You can just build one epic installation in some cheap country and serve the whole world from there. ====================::==================== Some independent corroboration of the AdoredTV Ryzen/Navi rumors https://hardforum.com/threads/adore...on-3000-series-leaks.1973015/#post-1043970615 There is a whole lot of reality in that video. I've noticed more misinformation in Funhaus content lately. Not major stuff of course, but just the little things that are easy to make a slip up on, but can heavily influence the opinion of viewers. For example, they when discussing Battlefield 5's weird release schedule they said Origin Access is a streaming service like PSNow. It's not, it's a subscription service and you download all the games. That's a minor but obviously *major* detail. I think it's the same thing again here. Slipping up on something silly, but just enough that it completely influences the narrative of the story. I know they have busy schedules but it feels like they need to dive just a bit deeper into stories these days. If not, I dunno what's going on but there's been an uptick in this since Gaming Weekly began. Hope that makes sense... nan

The PS2 and PS4 aspects of PSNow are basically the same as Game Pass at this stage (downloadable) Ans SIE is actually larger than "12 studios" makes it sound (13 actually, but that doesn't matter). "Japan Studio" is actually multiple studios, and Santa Monica and Sucker Punch both have 2 studios now afaik. Sony is *definitely* going to want to tie down Insomniac to a longer term contract to keep them in their exclusive library (Insomniac will likely keep some teams doing outside work, they prize their independence and have multiplatform ambitions) Kojima is tied to them very tightly for the time being, as well as Quantic Dream and Supermassive. THey're still definitely going to want to expand though, especially with some of their bandwidth dedicated to VR, which is simply not that mainstream (but which remains a decent exclusive draw) nan

Contents: HeresJohnny said: The other big problem for these streaming services is that the number of people who play video games is incredibly small when compared to the number of people who watch movies and television content, yet games often cost just as much (if not more) than movies and tv shows to make. Trying to use Netflix as a basis for successful, profitable game streaming service doesn't work because the audiences aren't even comparable in both size and frequency of use. Then you get into the whole content thing and that's another can of worms entirely. Unless you have a steady stream of consistent content, people will simply use the service sporadically, signing up for the shortest amount of time available and then cancelling once they've finished the game they were interested in. If you think publishers stick their big snouts into game production now by forcing unrealistic timelines and cutting content out to sell later as DLC, just wait until they start up a fledgling streaming service that is starved for content. Truthfully, the only people I've seen truly excited about game streaming services are those whose favored platform isn't doing so well selling games conventionally. I don't think Sony gives a fuck about streaming when they're having no problem getting people to buy shit conventionally or digitally. Streaming may make sense at some point in the future, but it also may very well not -- hinging your platform's success on it would be just as unwise as releasing a $500-$600 machine on the market and hoping for the best. At some point you have to have a PLAN, not just another hail Mary thrown, but a genuine plan, and not just a "well hell, that didn't work, let's try out this newfangled streaming thing, I hear the kiddos love that." Sony cheerleader obviously lol. So what does that say about the people who were excited when Sony bought Gaikai for 500 million to do psnow??? nan

Contents: Heyo. Watched the video from LTT ([https://youtu.be/0BQ4bXNdEQI](https://youtu.be/0BQ4bXNdEQI)) about the Shadow game streaming service and it got me thinking about what the future is for game development? On the more macro side, Services like Xbox's Game Pass and Playstation Now allow you to pay a fee per month to access a whole library of games, but how do developers get compensated? What values/metrics are the games being judged on? And how can this be sustainable for any business? Where do indie developers fit into all this? As for micro focus, how does this affect decisions we make when developing; Here's an example: in a world where a large portion of your players stream and your game can be played on everything from a TV to a phone to a set-top box on a desk, what do you prioritize: Mouse or keyboard? How do you balance multiplayer to handle these differences? What about building in features to compensate for latency for players with a worse connection; should some players get a boost to their "stickiness" when aiming if their ping is low? Exciting times! nan

We do NOT know what Sonys plan is for PS5 and BC and whether it will be like Xbox or if it will be locked behind the PSNOW service. Contents: Wes68 said: ↑ nookfan said: ↑ Nintendo needs to find a name and stick to it. Wii Shop Channel, Virtual Console, WiiWare, DSi Shop, eShop, now Switch Online Shop. Personally, I really liked eShop. Short and to the point and it was consistent across all their platforms at the time (3DS, Wii U, Switch). Now here we go again with another name. Click to expand... This. Consistency is something that I feel consumers find security and confidence in. If you have a good experience with something? Your likely to be a repeat customer from that same establishment be it a brick and mortar store or a digita storefront. Name association is incredibly strong and Nintendo continually changing names just to be 'cute' I feel risks muddying the messaging. Click to expand... Nintendo continually calls each hardware system something completely different...seems to be fine with consumers. Creating a new online ecosystem to coincide with a new hardware ecosystem...seems perfectly par for course? I don’t see it being that much more “confusing or muddying” than calling this the Switch compared to Wii U 2 or Wii 3 Wes68 said: ↑ But that's the thing I don't get. I don't see why they have to consistently rebrand an online shop? It's not like branding their hardware. I mean a digital storefront is a digital storefront. Steam, GOG Galaxy, B.net. These are so well known because they have been consistent. And yes I realize these platforms are on PC rather than console where the console is a closed ecosystem. They update from time to time. But the name has largely stayed the same. Click to expand... You are talking about stand alone services...they live and die on their service, so maintaining continuity with the name branding of the service is important. Name branding an app where you go to digitally download Nintendo games on a given piece of hardware...really doesn’t need continuity on its own. Making it unique to brand the piece of Nintendo hardware it’s connected to is more important. Wii shop should be how we think about the Wii. Eshop should be how we think about the 3ds (the Wii U tried to have it both ways...) It’s ok to rebrand an online service if it’s doing something different than what came before it. Notice it’s “gamepass”...not “xboxlive pro”. Notice it’s “PsNow”...not “psn plus*plus”. I would have to assume that the new shop they unveil on the Switch will be different enough in look and services that not calling it “eshop” will make sense. To your point about "Why roll out a brand new Nintendo Online network with the launch of the Switch with the risk of the Switch bombing?" Well why roll out a brand new Nintendo Online Network now then? Clearly the Switch is doing well now as it is. It's not like they need to rebrand their online network when the switch is doing well as is. Rather then them rebranding their shop? I'd rather see them actually focusing on some of the issues the eshop has. Now it's possible that maybe they do that in the process of such a rebrand. But I have my doubts about that when it took them as long as it has to get where they are with their online right now. Click to expand... Well Wii shop and eshop were just digital store fronts...that’s it. They weren’t really services. Wii VC and Wii U VC was another type of digital store front tacked on along side it. The online service Nintendo is attempting to roll out now is more of an all encompassing service...similar to what microsoft and Sony have been doing for a decade now. Before now it’s been a hodgepodge of Nintendo Network ID’s, Nintendo accounts, friend codes, Wii numbers, eshop accounts..Nintendo wanted to streamline and unify it since the end of the Wii console. Now they they committed to unifying their hardware under one ecosystem...it makes sense to tie that all together. Nintendo Online was always the plan regardless of Switch success or not...but what Switch success has allowed is for Nintendo to completely overhaul everything under their new Online banner. Again, their approach to their digital store front going forward will probably be way different enough to warrant branding it something else beside “eshop” nan

The point of innovation is to break boundaries and change the game. If you’re doing neither you aren’t bringing anything to the table. And by default you will lose. Contents: If possible, make a new Playstation account and make it an American one. Only use this account for PsNow. You’ll have to pick an existing address. I suggest a vacant address or something like a random fast-food restaurant or something in the US (lol not sure if this is illegal but what the hell). After making this account you’ll need to buy an American PSN card/code worth 20 dollars. Use this code to add those 20 dollars to your American playstation wallet. With these 20 dollars you can buy one month (I think) of PsNow for that account. Result: Enjoy Yakuza 4 and 5 and all other PSNow games. It will feel a little wonky at first after playing Kiwami 2, but once you get used to it its amazing! nan
